repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:
The "tohtml" module should not occupy a top-level place in the require() search path.

Solution:
Place it in the "nvim" namespace (`require('nvim.tohtml')`).

This is a "breaking" change but I doubt anything is require()ing this module.

Todo:

- (followup) also move "editorconfig" and "man"?

comment_data.body: need to figure out what's going on with these tags but the old docs were also broken like this
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,50 @@
+*lua-plugins.txt*  Nvim
+
+
+                            NVIM REFERENCE MANUAL
+
+                                       Type |gO| to see the table of contents.
+
+==============================================================================
+Lua plugins included with Nvim
+
+Nvim includes various Lua plugins or modules which may provide commands (such
+as :TOhtml) or modules that you can optionally require(). These are not part
+of the |lua-stdlib|, that is, they are not available from the global `vim`
+module namespace.
+
+
+==============================================================================
+Lua plugin: tohtml                                                    *tohtml*
+
+
+:[range]TOhtml {file}                                                *:TOhtml*
+Converts the buffer shown in the current window to HTML, opens the generated
+HTML in a new split window, and saves its contents to {file}. If {file} is not
+given, a temporary file (created by |tempname()|) is used.
+
+
+nvim.tohtml.tohtml({winid}, {opt})          *nvim.tohtml.nvim.tohtml.tohtml()*

comment_data.body:
maybe should name this `runtime-plugins`

don't need a separate helpful for every builtin plugin. except major ones with a lot of surface area.

This tag would make me think `nvim` is a global table like `vim`

And would PR https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/32995 need to support this tag?

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
Nvim includes various Lua plugins or modules which may provide commands (such
as |:TOhtml|) or modules that you can optionally |require()| as `nvim.{plugin-name}`
(eg. `require('nvim.tohtml')`). These are not part of the |lua-stdlib|, that is,
they are not available from the global `vim` module namespace.
```

comment_regular_data.body: I'm not sure of the files in `lua/` are apart of the public interface. If not, can we prefix them with `_`?

> I'm not sure of the files in `lua/` are apart of the public interface. If not, can we prefix them with `_`?

I thought `tohtml()` is intended for downstream usage? But yes, 

- underscore for things we don't want to expose
- for builtin plugins that we want to expose in `require()` but not `vim.*`, they should be namespaced some how. current proposal is `require('nvim.x')` but could also consider `require('vim.opt.x')` or `require('vim.x')` (might be confusing since it won't be available on the `vim` global?)

> current proposal is require('nvim.x') but could also consider require('vim.opt.x') or require('vim.x')

I vote for `nvim.x`, which also aligns with `:h dev-namespace`

I think having both `runtime/lua/nvim` and `runtime/lua/vim` is confusing. It is already confusing for new contributors if a runtime file is Vim-owned or Nvim-owned. Having both `nvim/` and `vim/` can mistakingly be interpreted as a difference between ownerships of the files in those directories. I think `vim.opt` is a better fit: keeps everything in the same `vim` namespace and `opt` is a common pattern in Vim package / plugin directories.

One problem: The `vim.opt` interface for options...
I don't like either `nvim` or `vim.opt`. Just keep everything under `vim`. If it isn't public facing then prefix the module with an underscore like we do already.

> Having both nvim/ and vim/ can mistakingly be interpreted as a difference between ownerships of the files in those directories

~~I think we could just document that in `CONTRIBUTING.md`. It should be simple, since Vim doesn't own any Lua runtime files (and I don't think they will ever add first-class Lua support in the future)~~

Edit: `CONTRIBUTING.md` already says
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/d0aedd36dfe0ac4ed45ea93f471379c77f0c7905/CONTRIBUTING.md?plain=1#L16
Which should be clear enough

> One problem: The vim.opt interface for options...

Which luckily is already on the chopping block ;) Of course, for compatibility reasons, we can't simply switch from one second to the next.

If we want to mirror Vim precedent, we could use `vim.pack` or `vim.dist` -- or deviate with  `vim.extra`.

And, yes, if `tohtml` is moved, the other modules need to be moved as well.

> If it isn't public facing then prefix the module with an underscore like we do already.

The issue is not that it's not public-facing but that it's not part of the `vim` global. We don't have a good story for non-API (i.e., part of `vim`) but not internal (meaning if you can't find it, _good_) runtime modules.

If it's meant to be internal -- i.e., not accessed by users since we already expose the functionality another way or do not want it to be used -- simply moving it to `vim._tohtml` (and similarly for `_editorconfig`) is the correct move because consistent with how we already handle a large number of other modules. In that case, the move wouldn't be strictly breaking, either (because the old location was never documented).

From a brief grep through the runtime:
* `require('tohtml')`
* `require('man')`

are not documented; they're just used in `plugin/{tothml,man}` -> move to `vim._tohtml` and `vim._man`  to match other "internal implementation" modules. We should simply do that (which would not count as a breaking change), no matter how we decide to treat the other class:

* `require('editorconfig')` 
* `require('coxpcall')`

_are_ documented, though... (The latter is only relevant for PUC Lua builds -- and according to a brief Github code search, only used in our tests and the `lua-client`. But since it's an identical copy of the original `coxpcall` module, keeping it in the global namespace is not an issue and may in fact be the desired behavior.)

So that leaves only `editorconfig` (and hypothetical future "optional modules") to decide how to deal with. The simplest options are
1. move to `vim.editorconfig` and add it to the global;
2. move to `vim.editorconfig` and accept (and document?) that _some_ `vim.foo` modules are not exposed by default and need to be required;
3. move to `vim.editorconfig` and sherlock @lewis6991 "lazy require" so that having it in the global does not occur any costs.

TL;DR: I would prefer not to introduce a (so far unnecessary) distinction between "Nvim Lua API" and "Nvim Lua Runtime Plugins". We run a tighter ship than Vim (has in the past) so we shouldn't need to introduce our own "Lua hole" for things we ship but don't want to "own".

(The distinction between "public API" and "internal implementation" via underscores and lack of documentation we should continue to observe.)

> require('tohtml')

Oops, missed that it _is_ documented because the docs are weird (`tohtml.tohtml.tohtml()` o.O)

Honestly, let's just add everything that is not internal to the `vim` global. That makes documentation (including tooling) _much_ simpler, and the cost is not high enough to worry about it.

(If anything, the plethora of top-level `vim.foo()` utility functions are what makes the `vim` namespace unwieldy, not the modules...)

But if we feel strongly enough about it, we should create a new module doc attribute `@nodefault` (placeholder name) that is expanded to `Note: This module is not exposed by default and needs to be required first` (or some variante thereof) during docgen.

> Honestly, let's just add everything that is not internal to the `vim` global.

I really want to avoid that. The `vim` global has a quality bar that "builtin plugins" don't meet. The `vim` global is for the "stdlib", not random plugins.

It sounds like `require('vim.x')` or `require('vim.x.y')` almost meets your expectations, so I will look into that.

`vim._tohtml` and `vim._man` feel like the wrong approach, because those modules are intended for downstream usage, but at a lower quality bar than the stdlib. Anything intended for downstream usage should not be underscore-prefixed, else we're teaching people to just ignore the underscore.

I am surprised to learn that about `vim._man`; I was not aware that this was meant to be user-facing. Otherwise I would not have suggested the underscore.

And to be honest, I don't like this talk of "lower quality bar". I am all for lowering the bar of entry and iterating, but if we don't feel it'll ever be up to our (high) standards, it's not suitable for including in Neovim. _You_ might make this distinction, but many users won't -- and the "low(er) quality" will stick to the whole project.

But I won't argue further; proceed as you see fit.

> I don't like this talk of "lower quality bar".

Fair point, agreed.

But even assuming they meet the quality bar, adding every builtin plugin to the stdlib doesn't seem like the right practice. They are optional, and require() is the conventional and expected interface for loading them.



> I would prefer not to introduce a (so far unnecessary) distinction between "Nvim Lua API" and "Nvim Lua Runtime Plugins".

There are various things that we ship, such as Lua ftplugins, that can be require()'d (may require adjustment to 'rtp'), but are not present on `vim`...

(Not trying to argue; just clarify.)

> There are various things that we ship, such as Lua ftplugins, that can be require()'d (may require adjustment to 'rtp'), but are not present on vim...

These are not part of the "Lua" scope, though -- in particular, they _cannot_ be required (without manual `package.path` shenanigans). My point is that for files under `lua`, do we really _need_ to make a distinctions between "stdlib” and "plugins"? So far we have not, and I think that has made things better (compared to Vim). Especially since this only applies to a small number (2 or 3) of modules, which makes me believe that introducing (and documenting and _enforcing_) this distinction is not going to be worth it.

Or do you have a concrete plan in mind for adding more "plugins" that would change the payoff?

> Or do you have a concrete plan in mind for adding more "plugins" that would change the payoff?

E.g. the "comment" plugin may be exposed later, but doesn't need to be in the stdlib. And the "termdebug" plugin.

Want to establish a pattern because things accumulate over time, and it's hard to reverse later.

A distinction I can think of: things on `vim` are essentially "providers" that can be overridden, whereas plugins are not positioned as such. That will become a more common pattern.

Then I recommend proceeding via document annotation. That allows sharing implementation with the "official" API (default autocommands in case of `editorconfig`, `:ToHtml` in case of `tohtml`, `gcc` in case of `comment`), and makes it easier to "graduate" or "demote" things (simply change the docs and add to/remove from `vim`; no need to move files around). We would of course keep the convention that underscored modules are internal-only and not documented.

So the pattern would be:
1. stdlib: `vim.treesitter`, always available from the `vim` global
2. bundled plugins: `require('vim.editorconfig')`, included in the documentation (new category)
3. internal implementation modules: `require('vim._man')` (assuming this will stay internal), not included in the documentation

> E.g. the "comment" plugin may be exposed later, but doesn't need to be in the stdlib. And the "termdebug" plugin.

Aren't both LSP and treesitter arguably just plugins?

I don't understand or see why we need to make a distinction. What does that distinction gain?

Would `vim.async` be a plugin? What about `vim.pack()`? `vim.net()`?

I've always considered anything and everything nvim ships with (`$VIMRUNTIME`) as part of the stdlib, because to me that's what it is by definition. The only important distinction is what is and is not a part of the public API.

And whether something is available on the `vim.*` is just a matter of convenience, to avoid `require` which can be unnecessarily noisy.

> I don't understand or see why we need to make a distinction. What does that distinction gain?


Plugins are different in these ways:

- they are primarily adding user-facing features; their programmatic API secondary
- they may have "autoload" behavior (`plugin/`, `ftplugin/`, etc.)

> Would `vim.async` be a plugin? What about `vim.pack()`? `vim.net()`?

No. In all of those cases, the programmatic interface is the primary interface.

title: fix(runtime)!: move "tohtml" module
